The lymphoid - specific transcription factor <extra_id_0> Oct-2a <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is implicated in B cell - specific transcriptional activity via the octamer motif .

The transcriptional activity of both domains is strongly potentiated by interactions with distinct B cell - specific coactivators .
Recently , we have identified a repression domain located within the N terminus of <extra_id_0> Oct-2a <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( amino acids 2-99 ) .
When this domain was transferred to a potent activator , transcription was strongly inhibited .
In this study we present a deletion analysis of the N-terminal region of <extra_id_0> Oct-2a <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> to determine the minimal repression domain .
We identified a stretch of 23 amino acids , rich in serine and threonine residues , which was responsible for most of the repression activity .
We show that repression is strongly dependent on the type of enhancer present in the reporter plasmid as well as on the cell line tested .

The possibility that <extra_id_0> Oct-2a <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> can act as an activator and / or a repressor may have important consequences for the function of <extra_id_0> Oct-2a <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in B cell differentiation and other developmental processes .
